content.rendered:
I’ve decided that this year I’ll take a Red Hat Certified System Administrator certification exam, and It seems like a good opportunity to make a blog series in which I’ll share everything that this exam requires.

Red Hat Certified System Administrator certification exam shortly RHCSA from now on is according to official Red Hat site I’m quoting

“The performance-based Red Hat Certified System Administrator (RHCSA) exam (EX200) tests your knowledge in areas of system administration common across a wide range of environments and deployment scenarios. The skills tested in this exam are the foundation for system administration across all Red Hat® products.

By passing this exam, you become a Red Hat Certified System Administrator. If you choose to continue your learning journey beyond RHCSA, the credential can also serve as a foundational step on your path toward our highest level of certification—Red Hat Certified Architect.

This exam is based on Red Hat® Enterprise Linux® 8.2.”

So basically it’s all around Linux administration exam which tests you in all possible scenarios in which you may come across in day to day life or some more unusual scenarios as well.

I will be taking a new refreshed version of the exam with label 8 based on their new Red Hat 8 Linux version. This exam didn’t change significantly enough from 7 for me to talk about their differences. The one that changed heavily is RHCE in which is now Ansible and automatization the main topic. I’m planning on this certification as well but let’s not get ahead of ourselves.

Why did I decide to take certification?

I feel like there is always need to learn new things. Certifications are a great way to do this, because it pushes you out of your comfort zone to study topics that exams requires.

RHCE maybe seems like a basic certification for someone, but I think It’s a good way to start if you have some experience with Linux already. If you don’t, you should really start with an easier one. Here is the list of Red Hat exams in the tree diagram from which you can easily pick one, that suits your skill and knowledge level.

Why did I choose RHSA and not someting else?

There are many Linux or administration certification out there. I’ve done some research and decided to pick RHSA for a few reasons:

  • Red Hat is very respected company in Linux world and their OS system RH is one of the most used OSs (mostly larger corporation because of cost)
  • It’s a practice exam. This means it’s REAL WORLD situation scenarios and not just some pick an ABCD answer to this question like LPIC. In the way I see it EVERYBODY uses man pages, and stack overflow or just google when they new an answer. But the true administration skill is to apply this new knowledge on your problem, exam shouldn’t just test your memory, but it should test your ability to overcome problems.
  • Red Hat has many more exams you can do after RHSA, and It kinda lay a ground for a harder certification from them in which you need RHSA first
  • It simply makes your resume looks nicer. This may seem like a stupid point, but what’s the even meaning of all studying if you won’t get rewarded in some way after. Sure you’ll get rewarded in a knowledge, but if it’s only about knowledge to begin with you may just watch some YouTube video guide, and you are good to go. RHCSA is one of the few administration certificates which are well known even for non-tech hiring managers.

That conclude pretty much everything that I had on my mind regarding RHCSA. In the following series of posts I’ll share everything necessary to pass the exam, including the sources I’m using also with the practical examples.
